body: Hi Everyone, Unlike Honeybee/Radiance, Dialux primarily uses a view-independent Radiosity algorithm to perform lighting calculations. So, once the calculation is done Dialux has a lot more leeway in how the rendered image can be displayed. For any given view, Dialux omits a couple of surfaces for the room so that rest of the surfaces can be viewed well. [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/BODpoj00oNn8nb8rocvN4k-NckVUlVFCh92uHcrD-oX89vVZnBvb8bUwDWUT1rGLZmumFbTpx-f5fxXLrPbmNmWTvEEOdJgO/27201694442AM.png) I am not sure if something exactly similar is possible with Honeybee/Radiance. The closest options might be : 1. Get the geometric extents of the zone and then select the upper leftmost point (x,y,z) as reference. In radiance terms -vp x+0.5 y+0.5 z-0.5  and -vd 1 1 -0.5 should produce a somewhat useful rendered image. 2. The other ("lazier") option might be to simply use a clipping plane for all zones at a particular height. For example : [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/BODpoj00oNmdgh0cP9xlfnUtxaK6zZz3G32FAjhO7zPCQlNKIhb0onKb9RPQGdzlftJ9diTPu*yevm-0OZTcz4Y4R7BMJZoe/272016100011AM.png)[](http://api.ning.com:80/files/BODpoj00oNkZz1LkV5vTnKL8XtMThVXSjisRtoopudy0LBOQk1PsJVat*2NCl1MHp*egerXSqqU9bNhSMdvYaQMjydHhJBHb/272016100055AM.png)[](http://api.ning.com:80/files/BODpoj00oNlCcBBHrOqsIc33Gppv5UdalYVUO1odoXPrrxK3k1aaoNuS9NCYgDUr15bgm0kEz6QX-Grtv-OVgYLGaRK6CYwG/272016100132AM.png) (By the way, I never knew that Honeybee had a component for automating views !)
